moves.1. e4 Nc6 2. d4 d5 3. exd5 Qxd5 4. Nf3 B:
If  5 ... Bxf3 6. cxd5 Bxd1 7. dxc6 Ba4 8. cxb7 Rb8 9. Nc3 Bd7 10. Bb5

White's pieces are all easily developed and poised for castling meanwhile Black's Kingside are on their original squares.  So....
moves.5... Qd7 6. d5 Bxf3 7. Qxf3 Ne5 8. Qg3 f:
The dangerous passed pawn. 

The pawn is not as easy to take as it loooks
moves.16... Ke7 17. Nd5+: Kxe6 leads to Nc7  forking the King and Rook.
moves.21... Rd8 22. Nd5: If Nxd5 white recaptures with a protected passed pawn, freeing up white's rook while forcing black to babysit the e8 square.
moves.29. h4: Starting to create a second passed pawn
moves.29... gxh4 30. gxh4 Rxd5: Black is still trying to neutralize white's passed pawn and protect his own. White is working to create another passed pawn.
moves.31. Kg3 Ke7 32. Kg4 a5 33. f4 b5 34. a3:
Risky, black is going to capture white's a & b pawns giving black two connected passed pawns, but who queens first?

Rb2 protects the queenside but allows black's king to capture white's passed pawn.
moves.35. Kg5: If Rg3  36 Kh6 .... 37 h5 gxh5 38 Kxh5 and white has a pair of connected passed pawns.  Perpetual check is avoided by weaving the king down to the 3rd or 4th row.
moves.35... Rxb3 36. Kxg6 Rxa3: Material is now even but white wins the race to the queening square
moves.37. f5: Freeing white's rook and threatening 38 f6  Kf8 39 e7  Ke8 40 f7  Kd7 41 e8=Q
moves.37... Rf3: Black's rook is now tied down to either f3 or g3
moves.38. h5 Rg3+ 39. Kh6:
Again perpetual check can be avoided by bringing the white king down to the 4th row 39 ... Rf3 40 Kg5 Rg3  41 Kf4 Rc3 42 f6  Kxf6 43 e7 Rc8 44 e8=Q 

Other ideas 39 ... Rg8 40 f6  Kxf6 41 e7 Kf7 42 e8=Q  Rxe8 43 Rxe8 Kxe8 44 Kg7 a4 White Queens first with check giving the needed move to catch black
moves.39... a4: White's rook is now free to move.
moves.40. Rc2: Now if black attack's white pawn(Rf3) white responds with Rc7  and Rf7
moves.40... a3: Making preparations to queen. But white has other plans.
moves.41. Rc7+:
41 .... Ke8 42 f6 Kd8 (any other Rc8#) 43 e7  Kxc7 44 e8=Q
41 .... Kf6  42 Rf7  Ke5 43 e7 Rg8 44 Rf8 and white queens
OR
moves.42. e7+ Ke8 43. f6: Again freeing the rook for attack
moves.43... Re3: Trying to prevent white from queening but....
moves.44. Rc8+ Kf7 45. Rf8+ Ke6 46. e8=Q+:
and Black resigned.

This endgame took advantage of creating a lasting threat and careful planning.  In the endgame small moves can have big consequences and the decision to go for a win or settle on a draw may only be 1 or 2 moves farther than you've calculated.  Many of the endgame moves were calculated 5 or 6 moves for a difficult endgame this is a must.
